repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Environmental Protection and
            Resource Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is satisfactory,
            despite various limitations, and an uncertain
            sustainability, due to the weak follow-up of the project
            operational plan, which requires the regularization of a
            minimum number of staff positions, and budget allocations
            for operating expenses. Lessons relevant for future
            operations suggest that specific environmental problems
            should be addressed through simpler projects, at the
            provincial level, and that strong local ownership could be
            ensured through consultative processes, prior to emphasizing
            implementation of an institutional development process,
            which is dependent on socioeconomic, and political factors,
            and may thus require a long due process. Structural
            constraints within civil service functions, affected project
            performance, an issue which could be improved by emphasizing
            the efficacy of staff continuity. Additionally, procurement
            procedures should be agreed prior to effectiveness, to avoid
            the delays, and the weak technical assistance experienced,
            as a result of procurement disagreements; and, deficiencies
            regarding withdrawal applications, and the use of the
            Special Account, further delayed implementation, which could
            have been avoided, had an assessment of the project's
            financial management needs, been implemented at appraisal,
            or through a provision for advancing funds, with the full
            accountability of project directors. Although social
            participation conveys a higher potential for sustainability,
            because of the multi-sectoral nature of resource
            conservation projects, it is recommended that systematic
            community, socioeconomic studies be undertaken regularly.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Environmental Protection and
            Resource Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has two broad components:
            institutional strengthening, and environment and natural
            resource rehabilitation.  Under the first component the
            project will commence the strengthening of federal and
            provincial environmental protection agencies and initiate
            environmental impact assessments of new investments to
            develop a framework for introducing environmental policy
            considerations into public and private investment decisions;
            raise policy makers' and the public's awareness of
            damage to Pakistan's environment and natural resources;
            and develop professional training in environmental planning
            and management.  Under the second component, the project
            will undertake a series of subprojects, including studies,
            pilot, and operational work, to repair damage done to
            natural resources such as watersheds, rangelands, and
            wildlife populations. Nongovernmental organizations have
            contributed to the design of several subprojects.
            Subproject implementation will emphasize community
            involvement and monitoring and evaluation of subprojects
            inputs, outputs and effects.  The subprojects are linked to
            the institutional development in that they are designed
            according to the government of Pakistan's environmental
            and natural resource management policies, and will allow the
            policy formulators to see and monitor the effects of their
            policies, and, if necessary, adjust the policies over time.
            The project will also provide funds for staff training and
            technical assistance.
